releases.name: v0.1.0: first round of improvements
releases.summary:
# What's Changed

This contains the first round of improvements based on your feedback and data; further improvements are still planned.
- â¬†ï¸ Updated the auto-updater; if this page was opened when you opened an older version of XRFrameTools, this is why - unfortunately the earlier version is not able to suggest or install this update
- ðŸš¨ The binary log format has changed and is not compatible with earlier versions
  - âœ¨ added `Produced by: XRFrameTools vVERSION` line near the top so you can easily see what versions are compatible
  - ðŸ“ added data required for new features
- ðŸ©¹ Fixed incorrect scaling of FPS axis in live data when there is not a full 30 seconds of data
- ðŸ©¹ Fixed pausing live updates
- ðŸ©¹ Re-enabling live updates now works instantly, instead of taking up to 1 second
- ðŸ—‘ï¸ The first frame is now entirely ignored, as the time since the previous frame is required for meaningful statistics
- ðŸšš Changed the filename extension for logs to `.XRFTBinLog` as some file-sharing tools had issues with the old `.XRFrameToolsBinLog` extension

## Metrics

- ðŸ‘» *'Wait CPU'* is now hidden by default, as it is not an optimizable metric.
- ðŸ“ˆ Split *'Runtime CPU'* into *'Begin CPU'* and *'Submit CPU'*. To decrease *'Submit CPU*', you generally need to lower your graphics settings in the game.
- ðŸ“ˆ Frame timings are now constrained to fit within the frame interval
  - in games with a single-threaded render/frame loop, this does not do a difference
  - in multi-threaded games, it is possible for each frame to take longer than one frame interval to generate
    - the data shown in previous versions was technically correct, but confusing and misleading
    - the data shown now is more directly usable

See [the README](https://github.com/fredemmott/XRFrameTools/blob/main/README.md#what-do-the-numbers-mean) for more details on the meaning of the measurements.

## Usability

- ðŸ’„ Replaced the 'live updates' checkbox with separate start-and-stop buttons for improved clarity
- ðŸ“ˆ Core: copied *Frame Interval* to the timings chart, to make it easier to correlate overall framerate changes with more detailed measurements
- ðŸ“ˆ D3D11: the VRAM axis limit is now rounded up to the next 5GB
- ðŸ“ˆ D3D11: the VRAM axis is now labelled in multiples of 1GB
- ðŸ“ˆ NVAPI:  the P-state axis is now auto-scaled
- ðŸ“ˆ NVAPI: throttle reason indicators are now doubled in vertical size for improved readability

releases.name: v0.0.4: first round of improvements
releases.summary:
# What's Changed

This contains the first round of improvements based on your feedback and data; further improvements are still planned.

- ðŸš¨ The binary log format has changed and is not compatible with earlier versions
  - âœ¨ added `Produced by: XRFrameTools vVERSION` line near the top so you can easily see what versions are compatible
  - ðŸ“ added data required for new features
- ðŸ©¹ Fixed incorrect scaling of FPS axis in live data when there is not a full 30 seconds of data
- ðŸ©¹ Fixed pausing live updates
- ðŸ©¹ Re-enabling live updates now works instantly, instead of taking up to 1 second
- ðŸ—‘ï¸ The first frame is now entirely ignored, as the time since the previous frame is required for meaningful statistics
- ðŸšš Changed the filename extension for logs to `.XRFTBinLog` as some file-sharing tools had issues with the old `.XRFrameToolsBinLog` extension

## Metrics

- ðŸ‘» *'Wait CPU'* is now hidden by default, as it is not an optimizable metric.
- ðŸ“ˆ Split *'Runtime CPU'* into *'Begin CPU'* and *'Submit CPU'*. To decrease *'Submit CPU*', you generally need to lower your graphics settings in the game.
- ðŸ“ˆ Frame timings are now constrained to fit within the frame interval
  - in games with a single-threaded render/frame loop, this does not do a difference
  - in multi-threaded games, it is possible for each frame to take longer than one frame interval to generate
    - the data shown in previous versions was technically correct, but confusing and misleading
    - the data shown now is more directly usable

See [the README](https://github.com/fredemmott/XRFrameTools/blob/main/README.md#what-do-the-numbers-mean) for more details on the meaning of the measurements.

## Usability

- ðŸ’„ Replaced the 'live updates' checkbox with separate start-and-stop buttons for improved clarity
- ðŸ“ˆ Core: copied *Frame Interval* to the timings chart, to make it easier to correlate overall framerate changes with more detailed measurements
- ðŸ“ˆ D3D11: the VRAM axis limit is now rounded up to the next 5GB
- ðŸ“ˆ D3D11: the VRAM axis is now labelled in multiples of 1GB
- ðŸ“ˆ NVAPI:  the P-state axis is now auto-scaled
- ðŸ“ˆ NVAPI: throttle reason indicators are now doubled in vertical size for improved readability

releases.name: v0.0.2: initial public test
releases.summary: 1. Download `XRFrameTools-v0.0.2.msi` from below 2. Run XRFrameTools from the start menu, your desktop, or start -> run 3. Read [the README](https://github.com/fredemmott/XRFrameTools/blob/main/README.md) This is an initial public test release, supporting: - Frame rate and interval - D3D11 render GPU time and VRAM consumption - Throttling reasons for NVIDIA graphics cards (e.g. thermal limit)
